trial_identification.studytitle: Study of CABG outcomes on and off-pump (SCOOP)
trial_identification.scientifictitle: Randomised study of the effects on neurocognitive function, clinical outcomes and hospital costs of CABG surgery with cardiopulmonary bypass versus CABG without cardiopulmonary bypass in patients with coronary artery disease.

interventions.interventions: CABG surgery - eligible patients randomlised to on-CPB pump

primaryOutcome.outcome: Neurocognitive function measured with standard tests
primaryOutcome.timepoint: At 1, 3 and 12 months post CABG surgery

eligibility.inclusivecriteria: Patients for elective CABG. Coronary anatomy suitable for either on- or off-pump surgery. Not single LAD or left main disease. No previous disabling stroke or other condition affecting ability to complete tests of cognitive function.

trial_design.concealment: The allocation to the randomly assigned treatment groups (as described below) was provided by a central telephone randomisation service. The patient was randomised the day prior to surgery to enable set-up of the operating room. The patient and family remained blinded to treatment assignment as did the psychologist performing the follow-up assessments. Patients were reminded before each assessment that, even if they knew, the psychologist was to remian blinded to the surgical technique throughout the study.
trial_design.sequence: The online program at http://www.randomization.com was used to randomly assign patient to two parallel treatment groups in permuted block randomisation with variable block sizes. The block sequence was varied randomly. Study staff was blind to the block size and sequence.

sponsorship.primarysponsorname: The Sir Charles Gairdner Foundation for Advanced Medical Research provided competitive funding.

fundingsource.fundingname: SCGH Foundation for Advanced Medical Research

contact.name: Pamela Bradshaw
contact.address: School of Population Health University of Western Australia M431 Stirling Highway Ceawley WA 6009
